sentences: Juliette Lake Lewis (born June 21, 1973) is an American actress and singer.
section: N/A

sentences: She is known for her portrayals of offbeat characters, often in films with dark themes.
section: N/A

sentences: Lewis became an "it girl" of American cinema in the early 1990s, appearing in various independent and arthouse films.
section: N/A

sentences: Her accolades include a Pasinetti Award, one Academy Award nomination, one Golden Globe nomination, and a Primetime Emmy Award nomination.
section: N/A

sentences: The daughter of character actor Geoffrey Lewis, Lewis began her career in television at age 14 before being cast in her first major film role as Audrey Griswold in National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989).
section: N/A

sentences: She garnered international notice for her role in Martin Scorsese's remake of Cape Fear (1991), which saw Lewis nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, as well as the Golden Globe in the same category.
section: N/A

sentences: Following the success of Cape Fear, Lewis had a supporting role in Woody Allen's Husbands and Wives (1992), followed by the thriller Kalifornia (1993) in which she portrayed a childlike woman whose boyfriend is a serial killer.
section: N/A

sentences: She appeared in the drama What's Eating Gilbert Grape (also 1993), playing a young drifter.
section: N/A

sentences: Lewis gained further notice for her lead role as Mallory Knox in Oliver Stone's controversial satirical crime film Natural Born Killers (1994), which earned her the Pasinetti Award for Best Actress at the Venice Film Festival.
section: N/A

sentences: She subsequently starred in Kathryn Bigelow's science fiction film Strange Days (1995), and Robert Rodriguez's vampire film From Dusk Till Dawn (1996).
section: N/A

sentences: In 1999, Lewis had a leading role in the drama The Other Sister as a woman with mental disabilities.
section: N/A

sentences: The 2000s saw Lewis appearing in a series of supporting roles in independent features and studio films, and in 2003 she earned an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actress for her role in Hysterical Blindness (2002).
section: N/A

sentences: She went on to appear in supporting parts in such comedies as Old School (2003) and Starsky & Hutch (2004), and embarked on a musical career in 2003, forming the rock band Juliette and the Licks; in 2009, Lewis began releasing material as a solo artist.
section: N/A

sentences: Subsequent film roles include the sports comedy Whip It (2009), the biographical crime film Conviction (2010), an American romantic comedy The Switch (2010) and the drama August: Osage County (2013).
section: N/A

sentences: Starting in the later 2010s, Lewis worked more frequently in television, appearing in lead roles on the series  The Firm (2012), Wayward Pines (2015), Secrets and Lies (2015–2016), The Act (2019), and Yellowjackets (2021).

== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==

== Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===

sentences: Early life ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===

sentences: Juliette Lake Lewis was born June 21, 1973, in Los Angeles, California, to actor Geoffrey Lewis and his first wife, Glenis (Duggan) Batley, a graphic designer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===

sentences: She has eight siblings: brothers or half-brothers Lightfield (an actor who appeared in The New WKRP in Cincinnati), Peter, Miles, and Matthew Lewis; and sisters or half-sisters Brandy, Hannah, and Dierdre Lewis; and stepsister Emily Colombier.
section: == Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===

sentences: When she was two years old, Lewis's parents divorced, and she spent her childhood living between both their homes in the Los Angeles area.
section: == Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===

sentences: Her first on-screen appearance was an uncredited bit part in Bronco Billy (1980), in which her father played a supporting role.
section: == Life and career == | === 1973–1986: Early life ===
== Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===
== Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Early career and success
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===
== Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis made her first major screen appearance in the television film Home Fires (1987).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Howard Rosenberg of the Los Angeles Times praised Lewis's performance in the film, writing that she "lights up the screen."
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She subsequently starred on the television  series I Married Dora, which ran between 1987 and 1988.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: At age 14, she was legally emancipated from her parents (with their approval) in order to enable her to more freely work.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis recalled her emancipation: "I know that sounds all radical, but when you start acting when you’re younger, you talk to other actor kids and their moms, and they’re like, 'Yeah, if you want to get a job, they like on your resume to say emancipated minor versus minor, because you then can work over eight hours.'"
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: For a brief period, Lewis lived with actress Karen Black, who was a mentor to her.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: At age 15, Lewis dropped out of high school.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She subsequently had a minor part in the science fiction comedy My Stepmother Is an Alien (1988), before landing her first major supporting role as Audrey Griswold in National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She followed this with roles in the dystopian film Meet the Hollowheads, and the comedy The Runnin' Kind (both 1989).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: The same year, Lewis had a guest-starring role as Wayne's girlfriend, Delores, on the series The Wonder Years.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: In 1990, Lewis co-starred with Brad Pitt in the Lifetime television film Too Young to Die?, a crime film loosely based on the case of Attina Marie Cannaday, playing a troubled young woman who falls into a world of prostitution and drugs.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: During this period, Lewis herself was met with legal trouble after entering a bar at age 16, for which she was arrested and charged with underage drinking.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis first garnered international attention and acclaim for her performance as Danielle Bowden, the daughter of a family targeted by psychopathic criminal Max Cady (Robert De Niro), in Martin Scorsese's remake of Cape Fear (1991), also starring Jessica Lange and Nick Nolte.

sentences: The sequence is the heart of the movie."

sentences: Lewis garnered critical acclaim for her performance, and was nominated for a Golden Globe Award, as well as an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress.

sentences: Retrospectively, her character's seduction sequence was named one of the most unforgettable scenes in film history by Entertainment Weekly and Complex.

sentences: In 1992, she had a supporting role as a college student in Woody Allen's Husbands and Wives, followed by That Night, a coming-of-age drama set in the 1960s that marked the feature film debuts of Katherine Heigl and Eliza Dushku.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis appeared in several films in 1993, including Peter Medak's neo-noir Romeo Is Bleeding, in which she played the mistress of a corrupt cop, played by Gary Oldman.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She then reunited with former co-star Brad Pitt in the thriller Kalifornia, in which she starred as a childlike woman whose boyfriend is a serial killer.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Critic Roger Ebert deemed Lewis's performance in the latter film one "of the most harrowing and convincing performances I've ever seen."
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: At the time of filming Kalifornia, Lewis and Pitt had been in a relationship since 1990, though they separated the year of the film's release.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She subsequently co-starred with Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio in the Lasse Hallström-directed drama What's Eating Gilbert Grape (1993), portraying a free-spirited woman who befriends a young man and his mentally disabled brother in a small Iowa town.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis also appeared in the video for the Melissa Etheridge song “Come to My Window,” (1993), portraying a mental patient.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis then portrayed Mallory Knox, a murderous woman who embarks on a killing spree with her psychotic lover Mickey (Woody Harrelson), in Oliver Stone's controversial satirical crime film Natural Born Killers (1994).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Though the film was criticized for its graphic violence and inspiring of copycat crimes, Lewis's performance was praised as "sensational" by critic Peter Travers, and won her the Pasinetti Award for Best Actress at the Venice Film Festival.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: The same year, she had a supporting role opposite Steve Martin in Nora Ephron's Christmas-themed comedy Mixed Nuts.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis subsequently played a rock singer in Kathryn Bigelow's science fiction film Strange Days (1995), doing her own singing on covers of two songs written by PJ Harvey.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Though a major box-office failure, Strange Days went on to develop a cult following in subsequent years.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis also reunited with her What's Eating Gilbert Grape co-star DiCaprio, appearing with him in a supporting role in the crime drama The Basketball Diaries (1995).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: This same year, at age 22, Lewis entered drug rehabilitation, having been addicted to cocaine and prescription medication for several years, and completed the Narconon program within the Church of Scientology.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: The following year, Lewis had a leading role in The Evening Star (1996), a flop sequel to Terms of Endearment (1983), opposite Shirley MacLaine and Bill Paxton.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: She also appeared in Robert Rodriguez's action horror film From Dusk till Dawn (1996).
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: In the film, written by and co-starring Quentin Tarantino, Lewis portrayed a teenage girl who is kidnapped, along with her family, by bank robbers who take them to a bar in rural Mexico inhabited by vampires.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–1999: Early career and success ===

sentences: Lewis next appeared in Some Girl (1998), followed by The Other Sister (1999), in which she portrayed a mentally challenged young woman in San Francisco attempting to find independence.

sentences: The film received largely unfavorable reviews, though Stephen Holden of The New York Times praised it as "beautifully acted...  Carla is played by Ms. Lewis with enormous heart and sensitivity, and with body language so precise that you soon forget it is a performance."

sentences: In 2000, Lewis starred opposite Benicio del Toro in the thriller The Way of the Gun, and was featured as a vocalist on the track "Bad Brother" by the band The Infidels, from The Crow: Salvation soundtrack album, released on April that year.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: She then appeared in the crime film Picture Claire (2001), opposite Gina Gershon, followed by the independent lesbian-themed drama Gaudi Afternoon (2001), co-starring with Judy Davis and Lili Taylor.

sentences: The film received unfavorable reviews, with A. O. Scott of The New York Times writing that both Taylor and Lewis "overact like second-string sketch performers on Saturday Night Live."
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Lewis subsequently had a supporting role in the drama Enough (2002), playing the friend of a battered woman (played by Jennifer Lopez).
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Lewis received an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actress for her performance in the television film Hysterical Blindness (2002), in which starred opposite Uma Thurman and Gena Rowlands as the friend of a woman in 1980s New Jersey who receives a psychiatric diagnosis.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Additionally, she received an Independent Spirit Award nomination for Best Supporting Female.

sentences: Beginning in 2003, Lewis embarked on a musical career, forming the rock band Juliette and the Licks with former Hole drummer Patty Schemel.

sentences: The band released their debut EP, ...Like a Bolt of Lightning, in late 2004 through Fiddler Records.

sentences: She also appeared as a guest vocalist on three tracks by electronic music group The Prodigy's album Always Outnumbered, Never Outgunned (also released in 2004).

sentences: The same year, Lewis appeared in the comedy film Starsky & Hutch, playing the role of Kitty, as Reese Feldman's girlfriend, and had a supporting part in the Jan Kounen's French futuristic Western film Blueberry opposite Vincent Cassel.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: She subsequently appeared in the Johnny Knoxville-led comedy Daltry Calhoun (2005), playing the girlfriend of a Tennessee entrepreneur, and in the drama Aurora Borealis (also 2005), playing the live-in assistant of an elderly couple (played by Donald Sutherland and Louise Fletcher).

sentences: In May 2005, Juliette and the Licks released their debut studio album, You're Speaking My Language

sentences: In 2006, Blender magazine included Lewis in their hottest women of rock music list.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: In 2008, Lewis appeared in Rockstar Games' Grand Theft Auto IV, providing the voice of "Juliette", the host of fictional radio station "Radio Broker", along with one of her own songs "Inside The Cage (David Gilmour Girls Remix)".
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Lewis had a featured role in Drew Barrymore's directorial debut Whip It! (2009), about a female roller derby player, and also provided voice work for the animated science fiction film Metropia (also 2009), directed by Tarik Saleh.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: The same year, Lewis released her first solo studio album, titled Terra Incognita, through The End Records.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: In 2010, Lewis starred in a number of films, first appearing in Mark Ruffalo's directorial debut Sympathy for Delicious, about a paralyzed disc jockey, followed by the comedy The Switch (2010), in which she appeared as the friend of a woman trying to conceive a child through artificial insemination (played by Jennifer Aniston).
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: She also appeared as a murder witness in the biographical crime film Conviction, starring Hilary Swank and Sam Rockwell.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Though only featured in a small portion of the film, The Wall Street Journal deemed Lewis a "scene-stealer," and she subsequently won the Boston Society of Film Critics Award Best Supporting Actress.
section: == Life and career == | === 2000–2010: Film, television, and music ===

sentences: Additionally, Lewis had a role in Todd Phillips's black comedy Due Date, reprising her role of Heidi in Old School (2003).

sentences: === 2011–present: Television and film ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis's first film in 2011 was the independent drama Hick, in which she starred as the alcoholic mother of a young girl (Chloë Grace Moretz) in 1980s Nebraska.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She subsequently had a minor role in the Canadian drama Foreverland.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She followed this with the thriller Open Road with Camilla Belle, and a starring role in the short-lived series The Firm, on NBC as Tammy, assistant to lead character Mitch McDeere (Josh Lucas).
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Next, Lewis had a central role in the dramedy film August: Osage County (2013), playing one of several sisters (opposite Julia Roberts and Julianne Nicholson) who reunite with their dysfunctional mother (Meryl Streep) at their familial Oklahoma home after their father commits suicide.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: An adaptation of Tracy Letts's play of the same name, August: Osage County was a box-office success, grossing $37 million in the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis was also engaged in musical projects in 2013, contributing backing vocals to the track "Saint of Impossible Causes", on Joseph Arthur's tenth studio album, The Ballad of Boogie Christ.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She also appeared in the music video for "City of Angels" by Thirty Seconds to Mars.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: In 2014, Lewis had a lead role opposite Aaron Paul in the drama Hellion, as well as the independent comedy Kelly & Cal, in which Lewis portrayed a former punk-turned-suburban housewife.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis subsequent had a lead role as a music producer in Jem and the Holograms (2015), a film adaptation of the 1980s animated series Jem.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: The film was a box-office bomb, and received largely negative response from both critics and fans of the television series.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis followed this with a lead role as a small-town detective on the ABC crime series Secrets and Lies, which aired two seasons.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She also had a recurring guest role in the first season of the science fiction mystery series Wayward Pines (2015), co-starring with Matt Dillon.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Also in 2015, Lewis contributed vocals to the song "Stickup" by electronic artists Karma Fields & Morten, which was released on Monstercat in November that year.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis had a supporting role in the techno thriller film Nerve (2016), starring Emma Roberts and Dave Franco, about an online video game.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: In November 2016, Lewis returned to music with her first solo EP, Future Deep, which she released independently, marking her first musical project in seven years.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She described the EP as "an eclectic bunch of songs tinged with the darkest blues, contagious 60s garage rock and dance funk anthems."
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis subsequently guest-starred on season two of the comedy series Graves (2017), and then appeared as a reiki healer on the comedy series Camping (2018), co-starring with Jennifer Garner, David Tennant, and Ione Skye, adapted from the British series of the same name.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Judy Berman of Time magazine gave the series an unfavorable review, writing that Lewis is "underutilized, as usual.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: "Also in 2018, Lewis appeared in the independent drama film Back Roads, about a young man trapped by circumstance in rural Pennsylvania after his mother (played by Lewis) murders his father.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: She was also cast in a supporting role in Sam Taylor-Johnson's A Million Little Pieces, adapted from the book of the same name by James Frey.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: In late 2018, Lewis was cast in the premiere season of The Conners, a spin-off of Roseanne, playing Blue, girlfriend of Darlene Conner's ex-husband David Healy.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis subsequently appeared in Tate Taylor's psychological horror film Ma (2019), playing the mother of one of several teenagers who grow close to a disturbed woman (Octavia Spencer) in their neighborhood.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Ma was a box-office success, grossing over $60 million worldwide, and was nominated for a Saturn Award for Best Thriller Film.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis had a guest role on Hulu's biographical crime series The Act, chronicling the life of Gypsy Rose Blanchard and the murder of her mother, which premiered in March 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===

sentences: Lewis reunited again with Tate Taylor for his upcoming film, Breaking News in Yuba County, starring Allison Janney, Mila Kunis, and Regina Hall, filmed in the summer of 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2011–present: Television and film ===
== Philanthropy ==

sentences: Philanthropy ==
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Lewis has supported Little Kids Rock, a US nonprofit organization that works to restore and revitalize music education in disadvantaged U.S. public schools, by painting a Fender Strat guitar and donating it to an auction to raise money for the organization.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Lewis practiced Scientology since the 1990s, and credited its Narconon program for helping her rehabilitate after a years-long drug addiction in her early adult years.
section: == Philanthropy ==

sentences: Though a practitioner of Scientology, Lewis also identifies as a Christian.

sentences: It's just tools for living.

sentences: It's about understanding one's self and others and compassion and how to communicate better and how to live in this troubled society.

sentences: It's really basic, common sense stuff.

sentences: It has nothing to do with all this funny folklore that surrounds it.
